title: 110_hr4283
content: The Act may be cited as the "Literacy, Education, and Rehabilitation Act". It provides credit for participation in educational, vocational, treatment, assigned work, or other developmental programs. The "Literacy, Education, and Rehabilitation Act" amends Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code, to allow prisoners serving a term of more than 1 year to receive credit for participating in designated programs, up to 60 days per year. The "Literacy, Education, and Rehabilitation Act" allows prisoners serving a term of more than 1 year to receive credit for participating in designated programs. Credit is prorated and awarded within the last 6 weeks of the sentence based on satisfactory participation or progress in the program. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons determines the number of days of credit awarded. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons determines the number of days of credit a prisoner may be awarded for participating in designated programs based on factors like program difficulty, time required, responsibility level, rehabilitative benefits, and overall benefits provided. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons determines the eligibility for credits awarded to prisoners participating in designated programs, which benefit either prisoners or the Bureau of Prisons. Any person under the custody of the Attorney General is eligible for these credits, regardless of when they were sentenced or convicted. Prisoners participating in designated programs can earn credits for educational, vocational, treatment, and work programs. Foreign prisoners transferred to the custody of the Attorney General are also eligible for these credits. The text discusses amendments to sections 3624(b) and (c) of title 18, United States Code, regarding rates for satisfactory behavior. Conforming amendments are made to sections 3603(6) of title 18 and 994(a)(2)(F) of title 28, changing references from 3624(c) to 3624(d). Section 3 of the Act amends the first sentence of section 3624(d) of title 18, United States Code, by changing "10 per centum" to "portion." Section 4 states that the Act and its amendments will take effect after a 90-day period from the enactment date.
